item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

unlimitedorb:

If a tile chunk is 8 x 8 tiles, then how can a map region be 13 x 13 tile chunks? Do you mean 3 x 2?

Ah damn got my terms wrong, sadly can’t fix that but very nice catch. The 13 x 13 would be considered the players map, or as super_ said the local “buffer”. The map regions are designated by ‘Region A’ and so on so forth. The local 13 x 13 player map is made up of these regions.

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

unlimitedorb by region he means the local “buffer” or view of 104x104 tiles. it is a 13x13 grid of 8x8 chunks. 8x8 of these chunks fit into a 64x64 map file

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:11, topic:328236”][quote author=zachera link=topic=424624.msg3226981#msg3226981 date=1275676922]
104x104 is potential area view, yes.
64x64 is the area of the region in the cache.

When a region is loaded, it is divided into 13 pieces (blocks of 8) to load Items, NPCs and Objects faster.


With each pixel representing a tile, and each square representing an 8x8 section of a region, you end up loading 52 squares across the four height levels.
[/quote]
thanks for bumping a dead post that was answered months ago with no new information[/quote]I get so fond of the search function that I don’t realize the date.

Read full topic

64x64 is the area of the region in the cache.

When a region is loaded, it is divided into 13 pieces (blocks of 8) to load Items, NPCs and Objects faster.


With each pixel representing a tile, and each square representing an 8x8 section of a region, you end up loading 52 squares across the four height levels.[/quote]

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

104x104 is potential area view, yes.
64x64 is the area of the region in the cache.

When a region is loaded, it is divided into 13 pieces (blocks of 8) to load Items, NPCs and Objects faster.


With each pixel representing a tile, and each square representing an 8x8 section of a region, you end up loading 52 squares across the four height levels.

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:7, topic:328236”][quote author=zachera link=topic=424624.msg3219046#msg3219046 date=1275003505]

[quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=424624.msg3118618#msg3118618 date=1265295996]
32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code
[/quote]Thank you for this.

Also, why has nobody gone for the effort to make multiple map regions actually happen? We’ve all just been talking but nothing is really getting finalized.
[/quote]People have, but the system requirements are huge.[/quote]the client runs using about 130 MB RAM, how much of that is the actual map data?

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:7, topic:328236”][quote author=zachera link=topic=424624.msg3219046#msg3219046 date=1275003505]

[quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=424624.msg3118618#msg3118618 date=1265295996]
32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code
[/quote]Thank you for this.

Also, why has nobody gone for the effort to make multiple map regions actually happen? We’ve all just been talking but nothing is really getting finalized.
[/quote]People have, but the system requirements are huge.[/quote]

not really

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“zachera, post:6, topic:328236”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=424624.msg3118618#msg3118618 date=1265295996]
32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code
[/quote]Thank you for this.

Also, why has nobody gone for the effort to make multiple map regions actually happen? We’ve all just been talking but nothing is really getting finalized.[/quote]People have, but the system requirements are huge.

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:2, topic:328236”]32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code[/quote]Thank you for this.

Also, why has nobody gone for the effort to make multiple map regions actually happen? We’ve all just been talking but nothing is really getting finalized.

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Zeus14 Zeus14

@Zeus14 wrote:

sort of, its part of plotting the clipping data. It also suggests that the full clipping data is not plotted by a 104x104 view area but plotted in a 64x64 area to save memory.

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

that is plotting on minimap or something right? region’s are 64x64 and yes it does store actual values… id >> 8 = the region x and id & 0xff = the region y

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Zeus14 Zeus14
item.description:
@Zeus14 wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:2, topic:328236”]32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code[/quote]

So each region is 8x8 the area in view is 32x32 (4 regions) and the area loaded is 104x104?

and ive also noticed this

for(int i3 = 0; i3 < k2; i3++) { int i4 = (anIntArray1234[i3] >> 8) * 64 - anInt1034; int k5 = (anIntArray1234[i3] & 0xff) * 64 - anInt1035; byte abyte0[] = aByteArrayArray1183[i3]; if(abyte0 != null) class7.method180(abyte0, k5, i4, (anInt1069 - 6) * 8, (anInt1070 - 6) * 8, (byte)4, aClass11Array1230); }

so maybe its not just a hash maybe its storing actual values?

anInt1034 = playerX
anInt1035 = playerY

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

32x32 is actual area in view, 104x104 is ‘potential’ area in view, and, yes, there is the possibility of multiple maps being loaded at a time;

for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++) { for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
anyway, anIntArray1234 is the region ‘id’ or ‘hash’ set, anIntArray1235 is the map file id set (aClass31_Sub1_1068.method562 searches map_index table), and anIntArray1236 is the landscape file id set (notice how the first parameter is a 1 for this call as opposed to a 0 earlier – it’s the ‘is-landscape’ flag). note that if they’re not -1, a request for their file data is pushed into the 'ondemandfetcher’s request queue. later in a different game cycle, in the ‘ondemandfetcher’ polling code, you’ll see it will recognize a map or landscape file by the owner cache filesystem id and then pass the data to be parsed by the ‘map’/‘objectmanager’ code

Read full topic

item.title: Map regions?
item.dc:creator: @Zeus14 Zeus14
item.description:
@Zeus14 wrote:

When a client sends the map region packet how many regions are actually loaded?

Are regions 104 * 104 or is that just the area in view?

this suggests there is more than 1 region in an actual 104*104 palette

[code] for(int l23 = (anInt1069 - 6) / 8; l23 <= (anInt1069 + 6) / 8; l23++)
{
for(int j26 = (anInt1070 - 6) / 8; j26 <= (anInt1070 + 6) / 8; j26++)
{
anIntArray1234[k16] = (l23 << 8) + j26;
if(aBoolean1141 && (j26 == 49 || j26 == 149 || j26 == 147 || l23 == 50 || l23 == 49 && j26 == 47))
{
anIntArray1235[k16] = -1;
anIntArray1236[k16] = -1;
k16++;
} else
{

                            int k28 = anIntArray1235[k16] = aClass42_Sub1_1068.method562(0, 0, j26, l23);
                            if(k28 != -1){
							

                                aClass42_Sub1_1068.method558(3, k28);
							}
                            int j30 = anIntArray1236[k16] = aClass42_Sub1_1068.method562(1, 0, j26, l23);
                            if(j30 != -1){
                                aClass42_Sub1_1068.method558(3, j30);
									
							}
                            k16++;
                        }
                    }

                }[/code]

And does anybody know why they go +6 -6 etc…?

Read full topic
